Award.AwardTitle: Language as a Window on Prehistory

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Language is fundamental to being human, but very little is known about how language changes over time or how other aspects of human society may change in concert with language. Language is a crucial tool for investigating the past. While archaeology and genetics are also invaluable ways to investigate how cultures have changed, in many areas, language provides better preserved evidence for past contacts, migrations, and cultural change. A great deal of previous work has shown that languages change over time, and that they do so in regular ways. It is also known that speakers adapt their languages to their cultures, and that languages reflect aspects of culture such as politeness. However, in order to understand why the world's 7000 languages look the way they do, untangling the relationships between language and society is crucial.

This research uses the languages of Aboriginal Australia as a case study. Previous work by this research group has resulted in the development of tools and databases for exploring language relationships and studying how change in cultural and language systems may happen together. The researchers will utilize these research tools to shed further light on how languages change, using the existing data to develop new tools for investigating language history. Specifically, the investigators will study the patterns of sounds, words, and meanings in these languages to uncover how they have changed over time. Australian languages are ideal for such studies because of the similar population sizes and political complexity of the groups in the period before European settlement, as well as the sizable corpus of existing material. This study will add to this material and test hypotheses about language relationships using statistical and comparative tools. This will allow researchers to identify new languages in old materials as well as refine knowledge of how languages change. A substantial component of the grant work involves including students in cutting-edge research, including training in linguistics and statistical methods.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant, "language as a window on prehistory", looked at ways that we can see into the past when there are no records from archaeology. Using language itself -- words, grammar, where languages are spoken, and the like -- we can figure out a lot about the past history of human societies. This grant also worked on endangered languages -- languages which are losing speakers. We were able to reconstruct six thousand years of Australian history, even in the absence of written records. We also found that the number of languages in Australia has been substantially underestimated. Another area we looked at was words for color terms and how they change over time. We were able to study the way that language and cognition work together -- that is, our color perception constrains the ways that color terms change, but so do social processes.


Over the time of the grant, we published 31 academic articles and 5 book chapters. We also made research materials for continuing work that almost doubled the size of the Chirila database of Australian languages (to almost 1 million words). This means that we will be able to continue to work on the projects begun by the grant long after the funding is exhausted. We are developing a series of tools for work with archival materials, ensuring that the language treasures in archives across the world can fully contribute to the data science of language. 


About 30 undergraduate students have worked on this project over the life of the grant, including students who are now in top graduate programs or postdoctoral positions. Others are working on cutting-edge computational linguistics in industry.


With this grant we developed methods of working on languages remotely, so that work could continue even during the covid-19 pandemic. We've talked about this work at conferences and on online panels (available on youtube) so that others can benefit from this research.

In summary, this grant advanced knowledge about how languages work, how they chagne over time, and how language can be used, along with archaeology and genetics, to study past and human history. For its broader impacts, it helped with creating tools for language reclamation, in the training of students, including making STEM more inclusive.
